descriptions:

Title: Ecologies of Violence: Crimes against Nature in the Contemporary Cultural Imagination

This project, "Ecologies of Violence," proposes a groundbreaking framework for the study of environmental violence and its representation in cultural expressions. By integrating cultural memory studies and ecocriticism, we will develop an innovative ecological model to examine the intersections of violence, colonialism, and genocide, and their impact on the natural world. Our objectives include documenting how cultural expressions represent ecoviolence, analyzing the emotional and affective dimensions of these representations, and exploring how they can foster critical self-reflection and environmental crisis awareness.

Through a comparative and transnational analysis, we will investigate the ways in which cultural memory and ecocriticism can be reoriented to consider more-than-human terms. Our research will culminate in a comprehensive study of environmental violence in culture and a best practices guide for pedagogy engagement with cultural representations of ecoviolence. By providing a framework to think about violence and memory in more-than-human terms, "Ecologies of Violence" aims to contribute to the development of critical literacies about ecoviolence and promote a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between human and non-human entities. Ultimately, this project seeks to inspire new perspectives on environmental violence, cultural memory, and ecocriticism, and to inform strategies for mitigating the devastating effects of ecoviolence on our planet.

This project, "Ecologies of Violence," seeks to develop a groundbreaking ecological model for understanding violence and its representation in cultural expressions. By examining how literature, art, and media represent environmental violence, we will document the intricate links between ecoviolence, colonialism, and genocide, and analyze how cultural representations reflect on guilt, responsibility, and culture's implication in violence. Our research will also explore how these representations harness affect and emotion to relate to environmental crises and promote critical self-reflection.

Through a comparative, transnational analysis integrating cultural memory studies and ecocriticism, we will produce a comprehensive study of environmental violence in culture and a best practices guide for pedagogical engagement with cultural representations of ecoviolence. This innovative framework will reorient cultural memory research and ecocriticism to consider more-than-human terms, providing a new lens through which to understand the complex relationships between humans, non-humans, and the environment.

Ultimately, "Ecologies of Violence" aims to provide a critical framework for thinking about violence and memory in more-than-human terms, enabling scholars, educators, and the broader public to better understand and address the far-reaching consequences of environmental violence. By doing so, we hope to foster critical literacies about ecoviolence and inspire new approaches to environmental crisis relation and critical self-reflection.
